comments.commentBody:
Chess championships would be more popular in the US if vuvuzelas were banned from them.

(Just because no one brings them doesn't mean they've already been banned. There, I've run rings around you logically...)

When I filled in NUDIST for 44D, I waited with baited breath to see what photo Jim might put up in the blog! By the way, this is the fourth appearance of this word in the NYTimes Xwords since the last Ice Age...although I guess there probably weren't many nudists during the ice age, come to think of it...

46D Czech Currency - ha! I knew this one because I just picked up some Czech korunas at my bank last week in preparation for my trip. Life can be so aesthetic!

I am a happy camper to see puzzles from Mesdames Gamache AND Gorski in the same week! Why are their puzzles so very satisfying? They put me in SATORI causing me to spontaneously break into Mozart MOTETS...cheers all
haha! Michael Tide - that was a rib-tickler!!
Bidis may be for the poor in India (and curious travelers) but the middle and upper classes smoke non-bidi cigarettes as well, especially Wills.
This was easier than yesterday's (Tuesday)

Patricia, if "baited" breath is a problem, try cutting back on the garlic.

Sally, having swallowed cheese,
Directs down holes the scented breeze,
Enticing thus with baited breath
Nice mice to an untimely death."
-- Geoffrey Taylor, "Cruel Clever Cat"

I didn't know NFL players were negotiating contracts that paid them independent of performance. It used to be that if a guy wasn't cutting it anymore, he'd be cut. The team might lose some money, but if a guy wasn't performing, or someone else came in who was better, the lower performing guy was out. One of the beautiful things about the NFL is it's a meritocracy, and there is constant competition.

I'm morally opposed to guys getting paid independent of performance. If they're not doing the job, they should get fired like the rest of us. Players are already compensated independent of performance; it's called a signing bonus.

At this point, I'm happy to see Darrelle fork over $16k per day.

I agree completely with your assessments of DeSean Jackson, Jermichael Finely, and Ryan Mathews, but am a bit curious about Tom Brady & Steven Jackson.

You mention questions of Tom Brady are "durability" and "motivation". Aside from a freak knee injury by a player rolling into him, Brady has been pretty darn durable. Sure, he has had arm issues in the past, but he's played every game outside of the knee issue that he played through last year and seems completely healed. Unless someone has had chronic injuries that repeatedly affects season after season, any player is an injury concern.

As for Brady's "motivation", did Brady become Vincent Jackson? I don't think anyone needs to question Brady's motivation ever. How is he less motivated then any of the other QB's you mention (or less durable then someone like Schaub, who has played one full season since starting)? I agree that his weapons are in question, Brady is not going to hit 50 TDs anytime soon, and he may not even be worth a 4th round pick, but I think beyond the question of his teammates, the other risks are off the mark. I also think that after the QBs you metnioned going before Brady, only Rivers and Schaub (and Favre, but he looks like he may actually be done) are the QBs who actually have Brady-esque upside. After them, there is a huge drop off. McNabb? Eli Manning? Flacco? No thanks.

Steven Jackson, I understand the questions about his injuries and performance last year, but a RB that is going to get 85%+ of the carries for their team has a great deal of value in this RB by committee world we now live in. I see that an elite WR is of great value as well, but if you were not a S-Jax fan and were picking at #6, maybe going with Gore or Michael Turner makes more sense then going WR there. There will still be elite WRs in the 2nd round (Roddy White, Miles Austin, Brandon Marshall, or even Reggie Wayne.) I just think a RB who is the the entire offense for a team (even an awful one) is the rarest and most valuable of positions in fantasy.

It is unfortunate that the current administration hasn't learned the lesson taught time and again when a foreign power attempts "nation building" in someone else's nation: they need to do it themselves, in their own way, on their own schedule.

Iraq arguably is much, much worse off as a result of the US invasion and occupation. (Certainly the US is - imagine how all the money could have been used here.) One can only wonder how a Saddam led nation might have evolved. And now, its "deja-vu again" in Afghanistan. The only question is, how much money will be wasted, how many lives will be lost, how much destruction and destabilization will result.

Three million killed in Viet Nam to protect them from themselves, and they've done just fine despite the horrific destruction inflicted by our wonderful government. The destructive arrogance of the US when it comes to its interventionist foreign policy must be the worst since Germany in WWII.
Does anyone really see President Obama as connected to this war or the military in general?

You wonder how Americans would feel if what was done to Iraq and Vietnam were done to us- bombed cities, landmines left to maim the innocent. The BP disaster should teach us that the US is only one link in the multi-national food chain- so these are definitely issues to ponder.

The numbers below were generated from the Wikileaks Afghan War Diary data. For more information on their origin see below.

===============
Enemy Killed in Action (kia), Wounded in Action (wia) and Detained (dia):
Extracted from 76910 reports
12234 Enemy were killed in wia=0/dia=0 situations (in 3086 encounters)
(totalled up only in encounters where at the same time the number
of Enemy wounded and detained were both zero.)
15216 Enemy were killed in grand total (in 3727 situations/encounters )
1824 Enemy were wounded in grand total (in 804 situations/encounters)
7316 Enemy were detained in grand total (in 2372 situations/encounters)

Friendly (US and allies) Killed in Action (kia), Wounded in Action (wia) and Detained (dia):
Extracted from 76910 reports
336 Friendly were killed in wia=0/dia=0 situations (in 216 encounters)
(totalled up only in encounters where at the same time the number
of Friendly wounded and detained were both zero.)
1146 Friendly were killed in grand total (in 707 situations/encounters )
7296 Friendly were wounded in grand total (in 3688 situations/encounters)
0 Friendly were detained in grand total (in situations/encounters)

Civilian Killed in Action (kia), Wounded in Action (wia) and Detained (dia):
Extracted from 76910 reports
1310 Civilian were killed in wia=0/dia=0 situations (in 617 encounters)
(totalled up only in encounters where at the same time the number
of Civilian wounded and detained were both zero.)
3994 Civilian were killed in grand total (in 1457 situations/encounters )
9044 Civilian were wounded in grand total (in 2993 situations/encounters)
0 Civilian were detained in grand total (in situations/encounters)

Host_nation (Afghan soldiers) Killed in Action (kia), Wounded in Action (wia) and Detained (dia):
Extracted from 76910 reports
1286 Host_nation were killed in wia=0/dia=0 situations (in 604 encounters)
(totalled up only in encounters where at the same time the number
of Host_nation wounded and detained were both zero.)
3796 Host_nation were killed in grand total (in 1649 situations/encounters )
8503 Host_nation were wounded in grand total (in 3551 situations/encounters)
0 Host_nation were detained in grand total (in situations/encounters)

Background:
A few days ago I looked at three events on the wikileaks Afghan War Diary map and found two of them had something like 50 enemy dead 0 wounded/ 60+ enemy dead 0 wounded. At the time I thought it would be interesting to search all the battle events for situations where people were killed and there were 0 wounded and 0 detained and add up the total deaths for those situations.

Since then I've downloaded the full Afghan War Diary dataset and written a computer script that produces information regarding these matters. (12,234 enemy were killed in circumstances when no wounded and no detained were reported. See above)

I can provide the computer script and associated files for anyone interested to check the validity of the above output. Best would be for others to just write their own code from scratch. The most interesting comparisons are above. I am struck by the 1 to 7 ratio of killed to wounded for Friendly forces (US and allies) and the difference as far as the enemy is concerned. (15,216 enemy killed, 1,824 enemy wounded. For a seven to one ration, for 15,216 enemy killed, where do the expected approximately 100,000 wounded go? Why are the ratios so different? )

I believe other programmers can replicate these numbers quite easily.

I would like clarification why these ratios are so drastically different for US (Friendly) vs Enemy vs Afgan (Host nation) vs Civilians.

Interesting comments by the Iraqis. Just like my family and friends in Czech Republic, some of them still believe that we came there to steal their oil. It does not seem to be happening - not a bad alternative to deep see drilling, seems to me.

Our troops, fortunately, have not suffered large losses for this possibly lost case recently. Let's hope it stays that way. I have no idea why some 50,000 'instructors' should remain there by the end of next year - 1,000 would be more than enough. Obama is a Bush's clone on Afghanistan but I hope not a complete clone on Iraq. But who knows - I share the doubts Iraqis express.

Obama's spin is now getting quite extensive. Drop of rate of economy growth is hailed as a success, just tens of murdered Iraqis (by their own, we have nothing to do with it, thank god) as another accomplishment. Has he been reading 1984 and building a White House 'Ministry of Truth'?

The less we hear about Iraq the better. They may even get another Saddam - one dictator more or less in that reginon does not make really that much difference. They need time (some 500 year, I think) to possibly realize that there may be better ways (i.e. our ways, of course). Or not.

At least Obama is not an evangelist of democracy as his predecessor was. Lesser of two evils, indeed.

The citizens of the U.S. want all our troops out of Iraq and out of Afghanistan.
We want All of out troops out.

I hope to live long enough to hear one of my Presidents past, present or future to say to the American and Iraqi people that we have made a grave mistake to invade that country based on lies. And that many thousands of Americans and tens of thousands of Iraqis died because we lied. Not only we did not own up to our lies as soon as we knew that there were no WMDs in Iraq, We covered up our first lie with another by saying that we invaded Iraq to bring democracy to that country. In order to accomplish our goal, we had to kill off thousands of Iraqis in the process.
Our supreme leaders claim to be Christians. Yet, all their acts are contrary to Christian teachings. The Ten Commandments is one their most sacred documents and the basis of their faith. I now recite one of the most important commandments: Thou Shall Not Kill.
I don't believe our leaders are real Christians. If they are, why would they lied to the American people? One simple answer is that they are not real Christians, in name only. If they were, they would never have started a war that resulted in the death of tens of thousands of human beings.

Would you like to bet against this: That if Iraq becomes more violent, Obama the Peace Prize Winner and Mass Murderer will do another "surge"?? But the NY Times censor does not like Obama to be called a mass murderer: it is too true.

It is high time for the Iraquis to get their political house in order and fend for themselves.
Mission Accomplished. Now go fight amongst yourselves if u are so inclined, but kleave us out if it, thanks. Our soldiers have died, and our economy has suffered for NOTHINHG, thank you.

Ladies and Gentlemen....We did bring Democracy to Iraq....unfortunately, that includes the affinity to war and all its horrors.  Now, there is a whole new generation of Iraqis who only know war and violence. Wasnt that the idea Generals?

The Iraqis should be afraid. The truce is a false one, and once the forces are drawn down the civil war and sectarian violence will mount again. This is inevitable, as the settlement we imposed via the patched-together government we supported doesn't enjoy enough broad-based popular support to survive our departure. It will likely start off tentatively, seeing what remaining American forces do in reaction. But once they are confident we do not venture far from our compounds, all hell will break loose. No way to avoid it, and we should have recognized it six or seven years ago. What a terrible waste of human beings and national treasure. .
I try so hard not to get upset...because I know all the trouble I'll get.
The Iraq war was a waste of money and lives. Bush and Cheney should be happy that President Obama is not interested in bring them to justice.

This mess in Iraq is imploding in Obama's and the United States face, and the fifty thousands that are left there to pull Sonderkommando duty will face the same fate.

Ten years down the road, there will nothing left to see of the American presence except the destruction that the United States wrought, and a nation left without many of the cultural artifacts of their high civilization, without a leader and with unrest the norm, and democracy nowhere in sight.

Just as in Vietnam, a lost war and hundreds of thousands of civilians dead, displaced and destitute. Vietnam today is doing just fine, but Iraq will be decades away from fine.

We Americans are also not sure what the goals are in Iraq. Secure the oil fields makes sense. After that, the rest is war profiteering.

The war on Iraq was for the benefit of Israel who feared Saddam. We have successfully destroyed their history and culture by advocating the looting of Museums and destruction of books and libraries.

We sent out death squads in the spirit of Negroponte to kill anybody suspicious and to create a method of division, so they will fight each other.
We advocated civil war.
CIA and MOSSAD provided the explosives for the suicide bombs and roadside bombs, to enhance the war and increase fighting and motivation.

We kidnapped anybody and everybody and tortured them and then humiliated them with photographs that went world wide.

We indiscriminately killed women and children.

We used phosphorus bombs against the civilian population in Fallujah, which is a crime against humanity (and the Geneva Conventions).

No matter how America wants to play the propaganda here in America, the people of Iraq know very clearly where they stand an d where American policy stands.

If a group of Iraqi men carried out a catastrophic attack on the United States using nuclear or biological weapons, then it is clear that we certainly deserved it, after all we have done to them

I think they are pretty clear on Americas goals.

Americans don't need to know and really don't have any influence on the matter anyway.

If the world leaves Iraq to it's own means....there will a revolution. Unfortunately, Arab countries appear to need very strong leadership...one way or the other. At least you know where they stand..like it or not. And this seems to be heading East. Soon the whole middle east, and centeral Asia will be unreliable. But the west (specifically the USofA) cannot stop it.

The West has to find a way to work with the Arab and Asian nations.

The only other option is extremism on the wests part....not desirable..falls into their hands...

I don't see a solution, simple or complicated...

CORRECTION (In the previous comment - I mistakenly included, at the beginning, two paragraphs of the original article). Correct text:

The \"inflection of condescension\" (like this article) and \"a safer country than it was 2006 and 2007\" (but not 2003, when the US invader arrived on the doorstep).

The US is the invader and the occupier. We, this country, are responsible for what happens in Iraq.

We have made a terrible mess of another peoples' country. Our military adventure has caused the deaths of over a million Iraqi citizens.

The only legitimate question, for Mr Obama and the rest of us is, \"How should we atone for this crime?\"
